JUDGES: Alvina Gyulumyan;Corneliu Bîrsan;Egbert Myjer;Josep Casadevall;Luis López Guerra
TEXT: The applicant , Mr PERSON , is an NORP national who was born in DATE and lives in GPE . He was represented before the ORG by PERSON , a lawyer practising in GPE .
The applicant first entered GPE on DATE . On CARDINAL DATE he applied for asylum . His request was denied in final instance on DATE .
On DATE the applicant was convicted of shoplifting and sentenced to a fine of MONEY ( NLG ) ( CARDINAL ( ORG ) ) .
On DATE the applicant filed a second request for asylum .
DATE the applicant started cohabiting with a NORP national with whom he had started a relationship . The applicant ’s partner suffers from a psychiatric disorder .
On DATE the applicant accepted a deal proposed by the public prosecutor and paid NLG CARDINAL ( EUR CARDINAL ) in relation to an offence of shoplifting committed on DATE .
His second request for asylum was denied in final instance on DATE . However , the applicant did not at that time leave the country and neither was he forcibly expelled .

On DATE the applicant was convicted of defamation , destruction and attempted aggravated assault , committed on CARDINAL DATE , and sentenced to a suspended term of CARDINAL months’ imprisonment as well as to CARDINAL ORG community service .

In DATE the applicant married his partner and on DATE he applied for a residence permit for the purpose of residing with his wife ( verblijfsvergunning regulier voor bepaalde tijd voor verblijf bij echtgenote ) .

On DATE the applicant ’s request was rejected by the Minister for ORG ( Minister PERSON ) . The Minister considered that the applicant was not in possession of a provisional residence visa ( machtiging tot voorlopig verblijf ) . Such a visa is normally a prerequisite for the grant of a residence permit , which confers more permanent residence rights , and it has to be applied for in a person ’s country of origin . The Minister further considered that the applicant was not in possession of a valid document to cross international borders ( document voor grensoverschrijding ) . The applicant lodged an objection ( bezwaar ) against this decision .

He subsequently returned to GPE and filed a request for a provisional residence visa with the NORP representation in GPE on DATE . On CARDINAL DATE the applicant ’s request was rejected by the Minister of ORG ( Minister PERSON ) , who considered that the applicant had repeatedly committed criminal offences and that he had already committed his first offence DATE after arriving in the GPE . Furthermore the applicant had continued to commit criminal offences even after he had started cohabiting with his partner . The Minister of ORG therefore also dismissed the applicant ’s argument that he should be granted a residence permit in view of the medical condition of his wife , as he should have realised that the commission of criminal offences would affect his chances of a residence permit . Furthermore , it was considered that the applicant had never had legal residence in the GPE and it was thus for him to bear the risks involved in starting family life at that time . The Minister of ORG therefore found that , in these circumstances , Article CARDINAL of the Convention did not impose a positive obligation on the State of the GPE to allow the applicant to reside in that country . Moreover , it had not appeared that there was an objective obstacle standing in the way of family life being enjoyed outside of the GPE .

On DATE the applicant filed an objection ( bezwaar ) against the decision to deny him a provisional residence visa . He argued that the offences he had committed were only minor ones and that he had not reoffended since his last conviction of DATE . In the view of the applicant , his and his wife ’s interests in being able to enjoy family life in the GPE outweighed public order interests . In this context he also pointed to a letter drawn up by a social - psychiatric nurse to his lawyer , saying that the applicant ’s wife was suffering from a schizoaffective disorder , bipolar type , and that she had had to be admitted to a closed ward of a clinic after her husband had returned to GPE as the stress , loneliness and despair concerning the uncertainty about his return had become too much and had led her to take an overdose of pills . According to the nurse , it was realistic to expect that her situation would improve if her husband returned as he was the only stable factor in her life and exerted a positive influence on her . Although the nurse stated that a long - term stay of the applicant ’s wife in GPE hardly appeared to be an option , this was ultimately for her to decide .

On DATE the Minister of ORG dismissed the applicant ’s objection , considering that the situation of the applicant ’s wife had already been taken into account in the original decision and the applicant had not submitted any new facts or circumstances leading to the conclusion that the condition of his wife should be deemed a special circumstance . Moreover the Minister considered that the criminal offences carried a certain gravity , regardless of the fact that it had been DATE since the last offence had been committed . Finally , the Minister concluded that sufficient consideration had been given to the applicant ’s family life in the balancing of the public and private interests involved .

In his subsequent appeal ( beroep ) against this decision , the applicant argued that the Minister of ORG had failed to motivate properly why the condition of his wife did not constitute a special circumstance . According to the applicant , the Minister had not correctly balanced the interests at issue .

The objection which the applicant had lodged against the decision to refuse him a residence permit was rejected by the Minister for ORG on DATE . The Minister considered that the mere fact that the applicant was now in possession of a valid passport did not qualify him for a residence permit as he still did not posses the required provisional residence visa .

On DATE the applicant filed an appeal against this decision also , arguing that it was contrary to the principle of fair play to refuse him a residence permit for the sole reason that he did not hold a provisional residence visa . The applicant further submitted that the interests at stake had not been properly balanced since his and his wife ’s interests ought to outweigh the interest served by the mere formality of obtaining a provisional residence visa .

On DATE ORG ( rechtbank ) of GPE , sitting in GPE , delivered its verdict in both the appeal against the refusal of a residence permit and the appeal against the refusal of a provisional residence visa . Regarding the application for a residence permit ORG considered that this had been rejected on the basis of the legal provisions in force at the time the application had been lodged , and which required that the applicant hold a provisional residence visa . The court further held that the question whether or not LAW should lead to the applicant being admitted to the GPE fell to be determined in the proceedings relating to the provisional residence visa rather than in the context of the question whether or not the lack of such a visa should be held against the applicant .

In its second decision of DATE , relating to the refusal to issue the applicant a provisional residence visa , ORG considered that the Minister had had sufficient regard to the psychological problems of the applicant ’s wife . It further found that it had not been unreasonable for the Minister to attach more weight to the interests of the community than to the private interests of the applicant . ORG took into account that the applicant had been convicted of a number of criminal offences ; that he had not held a residence permit when he started a relationship in DATE or when he married in DATE ; that he had committed offences during the time he had been cohabiting ; that the applicant ’s wife was thus aware of the fact that she was living with , and subsequently married , a repeat offender ; and that it could not be said that the applicant had committed minor offences only . In the opinion of the court , the ORG was also not under a positive obligation to admit the applicant . In this context it inter alia considered that it had not appeared that there were any objective obstacles to family life being continued in GPE , the mere claim that settlement in the latter country was not a realistic option for the applicant ’s wife not having been substantiated .

On DATE the applicant lodged a further appeal ( hoger beroep ) against both judgments of ORG to ORG of ORG ( GPE bestuursrechtspraak PERSON ) . In his appeal in the procedure against the Minister for ORG , the applicant argued inter alia that the Minister was obliged to examine the application for a residence permit also in the light of Article CARDINAL instead of restricting that examination to the proceedings relating to the request for a provisional residence visa .

In the accompanying appeal in the procedure to deny him a provisional residence visa , the applicant argued that insufficient account had been taken of his wife ’s psychological problems , that ORG had failed to acknowledge that the original decision by the Minister of ORG did not contain a proper balancing of the interests involved and that no weight had been given to the fact that the applicant and his wife were married . The applicant further submitted that no proper examination had been conducted of the question whether Article CARDINAL entailed the existence of a positive obligation for the NORP authorities in the present case . Furthermore ORG had failed to conclude that the original decision did not contain a proper motivation as to why the applicant ’s ( suspended ) sentences could lead to the conclusion that public order grounds carried more weight than the personal interests of the applicant and his ill wife , especially considering that the applicant had not re - offended since DATE .
On DATE the ORG dismissed both appeals on summary grounds for not raising any points of law .
It appears from the case file that the applicant ’s wife has visited her husband in GPE a number of times .
The admission , residence and expulsion of aliens are regulated by LAW ( Vreemdelingenwet CARDINAL ) . Further rules are set out inter alia in LAW ) .

As a rule , anyone wishing to apply for a residence permit in the GPE must first apply from his or her country of origin to the GPE Minister of ORG for a provisional residence visa . Only once such a visa has been issued abroad may a residence permit for the GPE be granted . An application for a provisional residence visa is assessed on the basis of the same criteria as a residence permit .

The Government pursue a restrictive immigration policy owing to the population and employment situation in the GPE . Aliens are eligible for admission only on the basis of obligations arising from international agreements , or if their presence serves an essential national interest , or on compelling humanitarian grounds .

Pursuant to article CARDINAL of LAW , a residence permit for the purposes of family reunion or family formation can be refused if the alien constitutes a threat to public order or national security . In this respect , article CARDINAL paragraph CARDINAL sub c of LAW reads in its relevant part that a threat to public order exists when :

“ c. the alien has been convicted of a criminal offence and sentenced to either a nonsuspended prison sentence or custodial measure , a community service order or nonsuspended financial penalty , or if , in relation to a criminal offence , the alien has accepted an out - of - court settlement or if a punishment order has been issued against him by a public prosecutor . ”

Under the relevant provisions of LAW ( PERSON ) , shoplifting attracts a prison sentence of DATE ( article CARDINAL ) , attempted aggravated assault , a prison sentence of MONEY and DATE ( article CARDINAL ) , destruction , a prison sentence of MONEY ( article CARDINAL ) and defamation , a prison sentence of DATE ( article CARDINAL ) .
